title: Psalms Chapter 62 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 62 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 62 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 62.

questions.question: According to Psalms 62:1, upon whom does the soul wait?
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:1 states 'Truly my soul waiteth upon God.'

questions.question: Who is described as the rock and salvation in Psalms 62:2?
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:2 says 'He only is my rock and my salvation.'

questions.question: What will happen to those who imagine mischief against a man according to Psalms 62:3?
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:3 states 'ye shall be slain all of you.'

questions.question: In Psalms 62:4, what do those who consult to cast a man down delight in?
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:4 says 'they delight in lies.'

questions.question: What does Psalms 62:5 instruct the soul to do?
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:5 says 'My soul, wait thou only upon God.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 62:7, what is the rock of strength and refuge?
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:7 states 'the rock of my strength, and my refuge, is in God.'

questions.question: What does Psalms 62:8 encourage people to do at all times?
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:8 says 'Trust in him at all times.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 62:9 states that men of high degree are heavier than vanity.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:9 states men of high degree are 'altogether lighter than vanity.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 62:10, what should one not trust in?
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:10 says 'Trust not in oppression.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 62:11, how many times has God spoken?
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:11 states 'God hath spoken once; twice have I heard this.'

questions.question: Who, according to Psalms 62:12, has mercy?
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:12 states 'Also unto thee, O Lord, belongeth mercy.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 62:6 repeats the statement that God is the rock and salvation.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:6 repeats 'He only is my rock and my salvation.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 62:8 calls God a refuge for us.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:8 says 'God is a refuge for us.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 62:1: 'Truly my soul waiteth upon ________.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:1 states 'Truly my soul waiteth upon God.'

questions.question: Complete the verse from Psalms 62:10: 'Trust not in oppression, and become not ________ in robbery.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:10 says 'Trust not in oppression, and become not vain in robbery.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 62 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 62 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 62, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God?
options: God is our rock and salvation, and we shall not be greatly moved.
We should rely on our own strength to overcome trials.
Trials are a sign God has abandoned us.
We must avoid all challenges to maintain faith.
questions.correctAnswer: God is our rock and salvation, and we shall not be greatly moved.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:2 and Psalms 62:6 emphasize that God alone is our rock and salvation, providing defense so we shall not be moved in trials. This teaches believers to trust God’s strength rather than their own.

questions.question: How does Psalms 62 teach us about the importance of prayer and pouring out our hearts to God?
options: We should pour out our hearts before God at all times because He is a refuge.
Prayer is only necessary during times of joy.
God only listens to those who are perfect.
We should keep our troubles to ourselves to avoid burdening others.
questions.correctAnswer: We should pour out our hearts before God at all times because He is a refuge.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:8 instructs believers to trust God at all times and pour out their hearts before Him since God is a refuge. This highlights the practice of continual prayer and open communication with God.

questions.question: In dealing with temptation to trust wealth, what guidance does Psalms 62 provide?
options: Do not set your heart upon riches, even if they increase.
Wealth is the ultimate source of security and happiness.
Trust only in your ability to gain wealth through hard work.
questions.correctAnswer: Do not set your heart upon riches, even if they increase.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:10 explicitly warns against trusting in oppression or setting the heart upon riches, teaching contentment and dependence on God rather than wealth.

questions.question: What does Psalms 62 teach about humility in relation to human status and power?
options: Both men of low and high degree are vanity and lighter than vanity.
Lowly people are unimportant to God.
Power and status should be the goal of a believer.
questions.correctAnswer: Both men of low and high degree are vanity and lighter than vanity.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:9 reminds us that human status, whether low or high, is vanity and lighter than vanity, encouraging humility and reliance on God rather than on human rank.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with bitterness toward those who speak lies. According to Psalms 62, what biblical truth should you share?
options: Some may bless with their mouth but curse inwardly, so keep your trust in God.
You should repay lies with lies.
Avoid all contact with those who lie.
You can depend on human justice to protect you.
questions.correctAnswer: Some may bless with their mouth but curse inwardly, so keep your trust in God.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:4 describes people who bless with their mouth but curse inwardly, which teaches believers to be discerning but to trust in God’s protection rather than seeking revenge.

questions.question: How does Psalms 62 instruct believers regarding where their expectation and hope should be placed?
options: Wait only upon God, for expectation comes from Him.
Place your hope in earthly leaders.
Put your confidence in your own plans.
questions.correctAnswer: Wait only upon God, for expectation comes from Him.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:5 teaches that the soul should wait only upon God because our expectation and hope come from Him, highlighting the importance of spiritual patience and trust.

questions.question: What does Psalms 62 say about God's power and mercy in relation to human effort?
options: Power belongs to God, and mercy is rendered according to each man's work.
Human power is greater than God's.
Mercy is granted to all regardless of their actions.
God’s power is limited by human will.
questions.correctAnswer: Power belongs to God, and mercy is rendered according to each man's work.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:11-12 clearly state that power belongs to God and that He renders mercy to every man according to his work, emphasizing divine justice and mercy.

questions.question: A person is feeling shaken by opposition and enemies. Based on Psalms 62, what encouragement can be given?
options: God is my rock, my strength, and refuge; I shall not be moved.
You must fight back to defend your honor.
Ignore God and rely on human alliances.
Retreat from all challenges to avoid harm.
questions.correctAnswer: God is my rock, my strength, and refuge; I shall not be moved.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:7 confirms God as the rock of strength and refuge, encouraging believers to trust God’s protection and not be moved by enemies or opposition.

questions.question: How does Psalms 62 guide believers in dealing with deceitful people who plan harm?
options: They plan to cast down the godly, but God will cause their plans to fail.
We should respond with deceit to protect ourselves.
Ignore the existence of such people.
questions.correctAnswer: They plan to cast down the godly, but God will cause their plans to fail.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:3-4 describes the plotting of mischief against the godly, but it also implies their downfall by comparing them to a tottering fence, teaching reliance on God's justice.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 62, God is only a refuge for believers during times of crisis.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:8 encourages trust in God at all times, indicating that God is a refuge continually, not only during crises.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 62 teaches that riches are a reliable foundation for security and happiness.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:10 warns against setting the heart on riches, teaching that they are unreliable and should not be trusted for security or happiness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "He only is my ______ and my salvation; he is my defence; I shall not be greatly moved."
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:2 clearly states God is the rock and salvation, emphasizing strength and protection as a foundation for faith.

questions.question: How does Psalms 62 instruct believers to respond to feelings of vanity and pride?
options: Recognize that all men, whether low or high, are vanity and lighter than vanity, fostering humility.
Celebrate one's status and achievements proudly.
Ignore feelings of vanity as unimportant.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize that all men, whether low or high, are vanity and lighter than vanity, fostering humility.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:9 teaches that human status is vanity, encouraging believers to remain humble and not rely on earthly achievements.

questions.question: What does Psalms 62 teach about where our glory and strength come from?
options: Our glory and strength come from God, the rock of our strength and refuge.
Our glory comes from personal accomplishments.
Strength is gained through human wisdom.
Glory is found in worldly possessions.
questions.correctAnswer: Our glory and strength come from God, the rock of our strength and refuge.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:7 declares that our salvation, glory, strength, and refuge are in God, teaching reliance on Him for identity and power.

questions.question: According to Psalms 62, what should be a believer’s attitude toward those who imagine mischief against them?
options: Trust God, knowing such enemies will be like a tottering fence and will fall.
Ignore God and try to negotiate with enemies.
Fear and worry extensively about their plans.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God, knowing such enemies will be like a tottering fence and will fall.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:3 compares enemies’ plans to a bowing wall and tottering fence, indicating their eventual downfall and encouraging trust in God’s protection.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 62 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 62.

questions.question: In Psalms 62, which metaphor best describes God’s role in the psalmist's life?
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:2 states, 'He only is my rock and my salvation; he is my defence; I shall not be greatly moved,' establishing God as a steadfast foundation and deliverer.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Psalms 62:2 and 62:6 where the phrase 'He only is my rock and my salvation' is repeated?
questions.explanation: The repetition of the phrase emphasizes the steadfastness of God, a common example of synonymous parallelism in Hebrew poetry, as seen in Psalms 62:2 and 62:6.

questions.question: What is the significance of the term 'rock' (Hebrew: 'tsur') in the ancient Near Eastern context as used in Psalms 62?
options: Symbol of stability and divine protection
A reference to a mountain deity
questions.correctAnswer: Symbol of stability and divine protection
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, 'rock' symbolized strength, stability, and refuge, reflecting God's unchanging protection (Psalms 62:2, 62:7).

questions.question: Which theme in Psalms 62 is reflected in New Testament passages such as 1 Corinthians 10:4, where Christ is called the spiritual rock?
options: God as the rock and salvation
questions.correctAnswer: God as the rock and salvation
questions.explanation: The motif of God as a 'rock' providing spiritual strength connects Psalms 62 with 1 Corinthians 10:4, where Christ is typologically identified as the spiritual rock.

questions.question: What is the tone of the psalmist towards his enemies as expressed in Psalms 62:3-4?
questions.explanation: Verses 3-4 describe the enemies’ malicious intent and duplicity, with the psalmist confident they will be destroyed like unstable structures.

questions.question: Which Hebrew literary device is exemplified by the contrast between the enemies' outward blessing and inward cursing in Psalms 62:4?
questions.explanation: The enemies 'bless with their mouth, but curse inwardly' demonstrates verbal irony, highlighting hypocrisy (Psalms 62:4).

questions.question: What instruction does the psalmist give to his soul in Psalms 62:5, and how does it reflect Hebrew wisdom literature?
options: Wait only upon God, reflecting trust and patience
questions.correctAnswer: Wait only upon God, reflecting trust and patience
questions.explanation: The command to wait on God speaks to a central theme in wisdom literature: trusting divine timing rather than human effort (Psalms 62:5).

questions.question: In Psalms 62:8, the psalmist urges the people to 'pour out your heart before him.' This expression is best understood as:
questions.explanation: Pouring out the heart is a metaphor for honest and heartfelt communication with God, as encouraged in Psalms 62:8.

questions.question: How does Psalms 62:9 describe the value of men of low and high degree, and what theological point does this illustrate?
options: They are vanity and a lie, illustrating human frailty compared to God
They are blessed and worthy, showing social status matters
They are powerful and wise, emphasizing leadership
They are equal in wealth, highlighting materialism
questions.correctAnswer: They are vanity and a lie, illustrating human frailty compared to God
questions.explanation: The verse highlights that regardless of status, humans are insignificant compared to divine reality, underscoring humility before God.

questions.question: Which cross-biblical theme is reflected in Psalms 62:10’s warning against trusting in oppression and riches?
options: The transient nature of worldly wealth
The necessity of strict law observance
questions.correctAnswer: The transient nature of worldly wealth
questions.explanation: This theme echoes Proverbs and Ecclesiastes where riches are warned against as unreliable sources of security (Psalms 62:10).

questions.question: What does the psalmist affirm about God’s power in Psalms 62:11, and how does it relate to ancient Israelite theology?
options: Power belongs to God alone, affirming divine sovereignty
Power is shared with earthly kings
Power is dependent on human action
questions.correctAnswer: Power belongs to God alone, affirming divine sovereignty
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes that ultimate authority and power belong solely to God, a core belief in Israelite monotheism.

questions.question: According to Psalms 62:12, how does God administer justice, and what ancient Near Eastern concept does this reflect?
options: Returns to every man according to his work, reflecting divine retributive justice
Favors the strong over the weak
questions.correctAnswer: Returns to every man according to his work, reflecting divine retributive justice
questions.explanation: This verse reflects the concept of maat or divine order where justice corresponds to human deeds, common in ancient Near Eastern thought.

questions.question: True or False: The psalmist in Psalms 62 expresses that his soul’s expectation is from men of high degree.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:5 clearly states the soul waits only upon God for expectation, not upon men of any degree.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 62 uses the imagery of a 'bowing wall' and 'tottering fence' to describe the stability of the enemies' plans.
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:3 uses these images to depict the enemies’ plans as unstable and doomed to fail, not stable.

questions.question: Psalms 62 repeatedly uses which Hebrew poetic technique to reinforce the idea of God as a refuge and strength?
questions.explanation: The psalm employs repetition, such as in verses 2 and 6, to reinforce God's unchanging role as rock and salvation.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 62 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 62 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 62:2, what is the reason the psalmist says he shall not be greatly moved?
options: Because God is his rock, salvation, and defence
questions.correctAnswer: Because God is his rock, salvation, and defence
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:2 states that God alone is the psalmist's rock, salvation, and defence, which is the foundation of his stability. This reflects God's attribute as a steadfast refuge (Isaiah 26:4), the rock of salvation (2 Samuel 22:47), and the defender of His people (Psalm 18:2). Jesus also refers to God as a rock in Matthew 7:24-25, emphasizing stability through faith.

questions.question: What does Psalms 62:3 describe will happen to those who imagine mischief against a man?
options: They shall be slain and become like a tottering fence
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be slain and become like a tottering fence
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:3 warns that those who plot evil shall be destroyed, likened to a bowing wall and tottering fence, symbols of instability and ruin. This aligns with God's judgment on the wicked in Proverbs 10:25 and the ultimate fall of the enemies of God's people in Isaiah 30:13 and Nahum 1:9.

questions.question: In Psalms 62:4, what is said about the people who consult to cast the psalmist down?
options: They delight in lies and curse inwardly
questions.correctAnswer: They delight in lies and curse inwardly
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:4 describes the deceitful nature of the psalmist's enemies, who bless with their mouths but curse inwardly. This highlights human hypocrisy, a theme also addressed in Matthew 23:27-28 and Romans 1:29-30 where deceit and hypocrisy are condemned as sinful behaviors.

questions.question: What command does the psalmist give to his soul in Psalms 62:5?
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:5 exhorts the psalmist's own soul to wait only upon God, demonstrating a trust and expectation solely in divine providence. This aligns with biblical calls to trust God alone (Isaiah 40:31; Lamentations 3:25; Hebrews 10:36; Romans 8:25).

questions.question: How does Psalms 62:7 describe God in relation to the psalmist's strength and refuge?
options: The rock of strength and refuge
questions.correctAnswer: The rock of strength and refuge
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:7 calls God the rock of the psalmist's strength and refuge, affirming God's unchanging, protective nature. This is consistent with other scriptures portraying God as a stronghold (Psalm 18:2), refuge (Psalm 46:1), and fortress (Proverbs 18:10).

questions.question: What does Psalms 62:8 encourage believers to do at all times?
options: Trust in God and pour out their hearts before Him
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God and pour out their hearts before Him
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:8 encourages believers to trust God continually and to express their innermost thoughts openly to Him. This reflects God’s role as a refuge (Psalm 46:1) and the biblical call to prayer and dependence (Philippians 4:6; 1 Peter 5:7; Jeremiah 29:12).

questions.question: According to Psalms 62:9, how are men of low and high degree described when weighed in the balance?
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:9 teaches that both low and high status men are ultimately insignificant, lighter than vanity when weighed, emphasizing human frailty and the futility of trusting in status. This is echoed in Isaiah 40:17, Job 7:17-18, and Luke 12:20, which emphasize human mortality and the fleeting nature of earthly power.

questions.question: What warning does Psalms 62:10 give about riches and oppression?
options: Do not trust in oppression or set your heart on increasing riches
questions.correctAnswer: Do not trust in oppression or set your heart on increasing riches
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:10 cautions against trusting in oppression and becoming vain through robbery, and warns against setting one's heart on wealth. This aligns with Proverbs 11:28, 1 Timothy 6:9-10, and Matthew 6:19-21 that warn against the dangers of trusting in riches and unrighteous gain.

questions.question: What declaration about God's nature is made twice in Psalms 62:11?
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:11 emphasizes that God alone possesses ultimate power, a truth heard repeatedly by the psalmist. This reflects the biblical doctrine of God's sovereignty (Psalm power belongs to God62:11; Revelation 19:6; Daniel 4:35; 1 Chronicles 29:11; Romans 13:1).

questions.question: According to Psalms 62:12, what attribute belongs to the Lord in addition to power?
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:12 states that mercy belongs to the Lord, alongside His power, and that He renders to each according to their works. This highlights God's justice and compassion, consistent with Exodus 34:6-7, Lamentations 3:22, Ephesians 2:4-5, and James 2:13.

questions.question: In Psalms 62:1, what does the psalmist say comes from God?
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:1 declares that salvation comes from God, underscoring the doctrine that God is the source of deliverance. This is consistent with Isaiah 12:2, John 4:42, and Ephesians 2:8-9 which affirm salvation as a gift from God.

questions.question: How is God described in Psalms 62:6 that reflects the psalmist's confidence?
options: God is the only rock and salvation, his defence
God is silent in times of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: God is the only rock and salvation, his defence
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:6 repeats the theme of God as the sole rock, salvation, and defence, emphasizing the psalmist’s unshakable confidence. This reflects the immutability and faithfulness of God (Malachi 3:6; Hebrews 13:8; Psalm 18:2).

questions.question: What does the psalmist instruct people to do in Psalms 62:8?
options: Pour out their heart before God and trust Him at all times
Ignore God in times of distress
questions.correctAnswer: Pour out their heart before God and trust Him at all times
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:8 commands people to trust God continually and to openly pour out their hearts to Him, which reflects God's accessibility and the importance of prayer (Psalm 34:17; Philippians 4:6; 1 Peter 5:7).

questions.question: What does Psalms 62:4 reveal about the nature of the psalmist’s enemies?
options: They bless with their mouth but curse inwardly
questions.correctAnswer: They bless with their mouth but curse inwardly
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:4 reveals the duplicity of the psalmist's adversaries who appear friendly but harbor ill will, demonstrating hypocrisy. Similar warnings are found in Proverbs 26:24-26 and Matthew 23:27-28.

questions.question: What does the psalmist say about the expected outcome for those who plot evil in Psalms 62:3?
options: They shall be slain and become unstable like a tottering fence
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be slain and become unstable like a tottering fence
questions.explanation: Psalms 62:3 states those who imagine mischief will be destroyed and become unstable, reflecting the certainty of divine judgment on the wicked (Psalm 37:12-15; Proverbs 11:21; Isaiah 10:5-7).
